The table of emission factors have categories under the column "Activity" 
and different countries as the remaining columns. 
This is the instruction on how to calculate an individual carbon footprint for either 
a single activity like a hotel_stay or more than one activity.
 If a person from Germany spend one (1) night in a hotel (hotel_stay), the carbon 
footprint is (1 room-night*13.2 kgCO2e/room-night) = 13.2 kgCO2e. 
Therefore, depending on individual's their carbon footprint can be calculate. 
If the person is involved in more than one activitity, the sum of their carbon footprint 
will be calculated. For example, we can use two examples here:
The person from Latvia bought 10 euro work of fish products and spent  2 a night at hotel.  
The total carbon footprint is 
(10 eur *0.8196 kgCO2e/eur) + 2 night *20.15 kgCO2e/room-night) = 48.496 kgCO2e.
The per capita of this per  is 7599.6065 kgCO2e. Since Latvia is in European Union (27), 
 the per capita for European Union (27) is 6890.2993 kgCO2e and the per capita for the World 
 is 6650.8427 kgCO2e. If an individual mention their activity or activities, their carbon footprint 
can be calculatedbase on the information in this file in addition to stating the per capita 
of their country, that of European Union (27) and the World.

Microalgae contribution in enhancing the circular economy drive of 
biochemical conversion systems – A review 
Kelechi E. Anyaoha

ARTICLE INFO  
Keywords: 
Circular economy 
Anaerobic digestion 
Composting 
Microalgae 
ABSTRACT  
The global impact of greenhouse gas emissions requires concerted efforts to reduce emissions and energy use, and 
to increase carbon capture and sequestration. Promoting the circular economy in CO
2 
sequestration systems 
optimises resource use and reduces the emissions burden throughout the supply chain. Carbon capture from 
anaerobic digestion, composting and fermentation (particularly ethanol) processes offers great opportunities for 
climate change mitigation. The waste/by-products generated from these processes can limit the need to source 
nutrients from outside the system and increase the potential for circular economy. The integration of microalgae 
cultivation with each of anaerobic digestion, composting and ethanol fermentation processes provides a new 
model for climate change mitigation of biogenic CO
2 
and circular economy. While this model is limited by high 
energy consumption and nutrient demand, seasonal variability, operational efficiency and end-user re -
quirements, further research and policy support will go a long way in realising the associated benefits, including 
in CO
2 
fixation, nutrient recovery, waste remediation and as an alternative source of animal feed.   
1. Introduction 
Rising temperatures due to climate change affect drought and flood 
regimes, rainfall patterns, groundwater reserves, erosion, glacier melt 
and soil fertility [1 – 3] . It affects infrastructure life span, social security, 
and economy [4] . Soil characteristics (water and nutrient availability, 
temperature changes, microbial dynamics), plant processes (photosyn -
thesis, respiration, diseases susceptibility, and nutrient uptake), and 
aquatic and terrestrial habitats ’ ecosystems will be impacted by climate 
change [1,2,4] . While some of these climate change impacts are local -
ised, there are overreaching global consequences with associated in -
crease in social inequality. Increased rainfall as a result of climate 
change may increase agricultural productivity in one region while 
reducing production in another, depending on the existing rainfall 
pattern. This will have a greater impact on rural farmers with less 
application of technology in determining yearly changes in weather 
conditions. A one per cent increase in temperature reduces agricultural 
income by 3.6 % [2] . In Finland for example, one additional day per 
month above 25 
◦
C increased mortality and acute hospital visits by 1.5 
% and 1.1 %, respectively [5] . There is a general consensus on reduction 
of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions as a climate change mitigation op -
tion. Greenhouse emissions reduction options include low carbon tech -
nologies and carbon capture systems. Efforts are also being made to 
reduce or eliminate the use of fossil fuels. While reducing fossil fuel 
combustion, for example, can significantly reduce greenhouse gas 
emissions, biomass use can achieve greater results because it is a 
renewable alternative. Of particular interest are emissions from 
biochemical processes. 
Biochemical processes include anaerobic digestion, composting and 
fermentation. While carbon dioxide (CO
2
) emissions from composting 
and biogenic sources in general are not considered in carbon reduction 
inventories, the composting systems ’ operations can contribute to an 
increase in GHG emissions [6] . It is important to note that the reduction 
of CO
2 
from biogenic sources is considered a negative emission [7] , as 
the CO
2 
is removed from the atmosphere during plant growth.

methane (CH
4
), and nitrous oxide (N

O) from composting are potent 
GHGs. The rate of emission of these gases varies from operational point 
especially when properly controlled. An additional benefit of biomass 
conversion in terms of climate change mitigation is the substitution of 
fossil-fuels with biogas from anaerobic digestion. Biogas production and

use has received varying levels of political support because of its 
contribution to climate change mitigation. In United Kingdom, for 
example, the Renewable Heat Incentive and the Green Gas Support 
Scheme were introduced to support energy from biological sources [8] . 
A similar support scheme for biogas was introduced by the Federal Re -
public of Germany under the Renewable Energy Sources Act [9] . Due to 
the relatively high CO
2 
content of biogas, its upgrading to biomethane 
has received increased research efforts, policy support and investment. 
This is particularly important so that the upgraded biomethane within 
the minimum standard methane concentration can be injected into the 
public distribution and storage network and used as vehicle gas [8,10] . 
On the other hand, microalgae cultivation plays an important role in 
biomethane upgrading and in general carbon sequestration. Microalgae 
are photosynthetic plank-like unicellular microorganisms found in 
lakes, rivers, ponds, and other bodies of water. Microalgae range size 
from 0.2 to 200 µ m [11] and are composed of lipids, carbohydrates, and 
proteins [12] . Microalgae are important because of their photosynthetic 
ability, which allows them to bioconvert CO
2 
into biomass faster than 
any other plant [13,14] . Some of the reports on biogas upgrading using 
microalgae include anaerobic digestion of food waste [15] , food waste 
with sewage sludge [16] , and sewage sludge [17] . 
Prior studies have reviewed carbon dioxide fixation and nutrient 
removal from wastewater using microalgae [18] , the use of CO
2 
from 
composting in controlled environment agriculture [19] , emissions of off- 
gas in composting [20] , biogas upgrading using microalgae [21] , and 
CO
2 
sequestration from ethanol fermentation [22] . These studies 
reviewed either sequestration of CO
2 
from one biochemical system or 
nutrient removal by microalgae. Other studies reviewed only the 
sequestration of CO
2 
from all sources using biological means [23,24] . 
There are limited review on integrating carbon sequestration and 
nutrient removal/recovery with biological systems in a circular econ -
omy approach. Therefore, this paper for the first time provides a review 
of available information on the current status, challenges, and future 
prospects of microalgae CO
2 
sequestration from biochemical processes. 
The influence and opportunities of microalgae in nutrient recovery and 
in closing the loop of biochemical conversion systems are presented. The 
process parameters of microalgae cultivation with respect to CO
2 
availability and utilisation, and microalgae strains are discussed 
providing useful information for the integration of microalgae cultiva -
tion with biochemical systems for improved circular economy, resource 
availability, and climate change mitigation options. 
2. The concept of carbon capture 
2.1. Carbon capture technologies 
Carbon (carbon dioxide) capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS) 
technology is used to capture CO
2 
at the point of generation or directly 
from the atmosphere and use it in industry, for plant growth or store it in 
deep oceans, and/or gas wells [25] . CCUS is a clear path to climate 
change mitigation. The CCUS process takes into account the CO
2 
sour -
ces, which include flue gases from combustion processes (biomass and 
fossil fuels), industrial processes (for example hydrogen production from 
natural gas), and biogas and syngas upgrading. In most of the processes, 
CO
2 
is released in combination with other gases of different composi -
tion. For example, biogas consists of 50 – 75 % CH
4

[28] . One of the challenges of CO
2 
capture is the removal of 
other gases or the recovery of CO
2 
from the target gas stream. 
Various separation techniques for carbon capture including 
absorption, adsorption, membrane and cryogenic fractionation have 
been widely reported in the literature [29 – 31] . In the absorption tech -
nique, solvents, including amine solutions, chemically absorb CO
2 
from 
the gas stream. When heated, the CO
2 
in the rich solution is vaporised, 
compressed, and transported for industrial use, storage in underground 
facilities, or in other forms of sequestration. Aqueous amine solutions 
include monoethanolamine and diethanolamine, triethanolamine, and 
methyl diethanolamine. Monoethanolamine is the most widely used 
amine solution [32,33] and the challenges include solvent degradation, 
corrosion, and solvent regeneration efficiency [32] . Adsorption sepa -
ration technology, uses the selective affinity of CO
2 
for materials such as 
zeolites, activated carbons, calcium oxides, silica gels, and hydrotalcites 
due to temperature and pressure differences are used to separate the gas 
from other gases, especially CH
4 
[21,26,34] . This technology is char -
acterised by lower removal efficiencies when compared to absorption 
technology [32] . Membrane separation technology uses materials that 
allow one component to permeate but not the other. Although, the 
process is energy efficient, it is limited by the fragility of membrane 
material under high temperature conditions [32,35] . 
Cryogenic separation, exploits difference in the condensation and 
sublimation properties of the gas stream components are employed to 
separate each individual gas. This technique is associated with high CO
2 
purity but also high costs [35,36] . In terms of CO
2 
reduction, these 
capture technologies are only one important step in the process. The 
captured CO
2 
needs to be used, stored or sequestered. While there are 
many unanswered questions regarding underground storage of CO
2 
including possible leakage during storage, high energy consumption 
during capture and transportation [37] , microalgae offer a clear role in 
the sequestration of captured CO
2
. In particular, the biofixation of 
microalgae can be carried out with or without the carbon capture 
technologies listed above. In comparison with other technologies, effi -
ciency is a limiting factor in microalgae carbon capture. However, this 
can be compensated by the fact that the CO
2 
loop is closed depending on 
end use of the microalgal biomass and microalgae carbon sequestration 
also include wastewater remediation and as raw material source for 
many products. 
2.2. Microalgae carbon sequestration 
While carbon sequestration involves the capture and storage of at -
mospheric CO
2
, carbon fixation is the process of converting inorganic 
carbon into organic compounds.

In particular, the biofixation of 
microalgae can be carried out with or without the carbon capture 
technologies listed above. In comparison with other technologies, effi -
ciency is a limiting factor in microalgae carbon capture. However, this 
can be compensated by the fact that the CO

loop is closed depending on 
end use of the microalgal biomass and microalgae carbon sequestration 
also include wastewater remediation and as raw material source for 
many products. 
2.2. Microalgae carbon sequestration 
While carbon sequestration involves the capture and storage of at -
mospheric CO
2
, carbon fixation is the process of converting inorganic 
carbon into organic compounds. Microalgae carbon sequestration in -
volves the absorption in the liquid medium and fixation by microalgae 
or other photosynthetic organisms/plants in the process of photosyn -
thesis [14] . The advantages of microalgae CO
2 
capture and utilisation 
include direct use of solar energy, sewage wastewater management, 
high bioconversion of carbon dioxide, high biomass productivity, high 
lipid accumulation, and environmental sustainability [32,38] . Micro -
algal biomass is used as a source of bioenergy/biofuel, human food and 
animal feed, medical drugs, biofertilisers. Therefore, it is an important 
feedstock for climate change mitigation. The CO
2 
fixing capacity of 
microalgae is 10 – 50 times higher than that of terrestrial plants [38] , 
with high photosynthetic efficiency and biomass yield [39] . About one 
tonne of microalgae can fix approximately 1.83 tonnes of CO
2 
[38,39] . 
Carbon sequestration rates of 93.7 % [12] and carbon fixation rate of 
3.53 g(L
.
d)
-1 
[40] have been reported. Cyanobacteria such as Arthrospira 
platensis (s pirulina ), play a similar role to microalgae in mitigating 
climate change because they are photoautotrophic organisms that use 
CO
2 
as a carbon source, and have also been included as microalgae due 
to these similarities [41] .

concentration from microalgae activity could lead to increased oxy -

2 
and 
dissolved oxygen concentrations ensures higher carboxylase activity of 
the RuBisCO enzyme and an optimal pH. Seyed et al. [14] suggested 
using sodium hydroxide or calcium carbonate to adjust the pH of the 
culture medium as the CO
2 
concentration increases. In this case, while 
CO
2 
fixation is enhanced, microalgal growth is not limited by the 
reduced pH. However, this is an additional resource that limits the cir -
cular economy of microalgae production in a biochemical system. Of 
particular importance is the microalgae response to different CO
2 
con -
centrations. In addition, the CO

including as CO

3. Microalgae cultivation – Integrating with biochemical 
systems 
Different CO
2 
sources for microalgae cultivation are air (0.04 % of 
CO
2
), industrial processes, combustion flue gas, gasification syngas, 
biogas from anaerobic digestion, gaseous waste from fermentation, and 
off-gas from aerobic digestion (composting). The CO
2 
concentrations in 
cement plants, natural gas- and coal-fired power plants are up to 35, 4 
and 14 vol%, respectively [57,58] . The presence of impurities or other 
gases especially SOx and NOx in the flue gas is a challenge for micro -
algae growth. Similarly, the presence of heavy metals including As, Cd, 
Co, Cr, Cu, Hg, Mn, Ni, Pb, Sb, Se, Sn, V, and Z from coal flue gas is a 
limiting factor, especially when using microalgal biomass as a food 
source [59] . While microalgae grown in coal flue gas for example serves 
as sink for heavy metals [60,61] , the metals accumulated in microalgal 
biomass could be toxic to animals and even humans when used as food 
sources [61] . 
Fig. 1 is a representative sketch of biochemical systems. 
CO
2 
in biogas is between 25 and 45 % [62] , while the concentration 
in fermentation in particular ethanol, is about 99 % [63] . Though, CO
2 
concentration in composting off-gas is about 4.5 – 12 % [64] , it should be 
noted that there is an almost linear relationship between air (oxygen) 
input and CO
2 
produced in the off-gas. In microalgal biosequestration of 
carbon from biochemical systems, more emphasis is placed on ethanol 
fermentation, and aerobic and anaerobic digestion. 
3.1. Integrated microalgae cultivation and ethanol fermentation system 
There is an increasing focus on replacing the replacement of fossil 
fuels with ethanol especially in automobiles. Emissions from the value 
chain are twofold: CO
2 
emissions from fermentation and CO
2 
emissions 
from bioethanol combustion. Emission from ethanol combustion is 
carbon neutral while sequestration of CO
2 
from the fermentation process 
is a net carbon removal process as the organic material has absorbed 
carbon from the atmosphere during the growth period. Some of the 
crops used for ethanol production include maize, sweet and grain sor -
ghum, sugar beet, sugar cane, barley, potato, cassava, and wheat 
[63,65,66] . Ethanol fermentation takes place in the absence of oxygen 
and in the presence of enzymes, producing ethanol, and CO
2 
as a by- 
product. The fermentation process involves the conversion of more 
complex organic materials (starch) to simpler forms such as sugars and 
subsequent conversion of the sugar to ethanol under anaerobic condi -
tions by yeast, fungi and bacteria with the release of CO
2 
[66] . Ethanol 
production from glucose can be described by the following Equation (6)

from the process is CO

3.2. Integrated microalgae cultivation and anaerobic digestion system 
Anaerobic digestion is the decomposition of organic matter by mi -
croorganisms in the absence of oxygen producing biogas. The biogas 
consists of methane, CO
2
, H
2 
and other impurities [21] . Nitrogen and 
phosphorus contained in the digestate from anaerobic digestion provide 
a nutrient source for microalgae cultivation [72] . More importantly, the 
CO
2 
in the biogas provides carbon for microalgae growth [17] . The 
biogas with low or zero CO
2 
concentration is known as biomethane and 
is a valuable fuel for heat and electricity production [73] . This is an 
additional benefit of growing microalgae using biogas. The concentra -
tion of CO
2 
in biogas can vary, but not significantly, for example 39 % 
(dairy cow manure), 43.3 % (chicken and cattle manure with vegetable 
and green waste), and 40.8 % (pig and cow manure with waste from the 
food, dairy and beverage industries), respectively [74] . However, the 
impurity, which consists of hydrogen sulphide (H
2
S) and ammonia, 
could be a source of concern in microalgae cultivation using biogas. 
High ammonia nitrogen results in ammonia toxicity to microalgae and 
causes damage to the manganese cluster of the Oxygen-evolution com -
plex of photosystem II Chuka-ogwude [75] . 
The integration of microalgae cultivation and anaerobic digestion 
integration offers many advantages including CO
2 
fixation, biogas 
upgrading, and biogas sludge remediation. Sun et al. [76] used multi- 
walled carbon nanotube concentrations of 0.0, 0.1, 1, 5, and 10 mgL
-1

vation. The highest COD, tetracycline and CO
2

and 57 % were recorded after seven days, respectively. Chlorella vulgaris

3.3. Integrated microalgae cultivation and composting system 
Composting is the breakdown of organic material into CO
2
, water, 
nitrate, sulfates, and biomass in the presence of oxygen and micro- 
organisms. The micro-organisms feed on the organic material while 
consuming oxygen and producing CO
2
. The rate of activity decreases as 
the unstable organic material component is depleted, resulting in less 
oxygen consumption and CO
2 
generation. As the process is exothermic, 
the type of microorganisms in the system varies with temperature. CO
2 
is an important generated off-gas component of the aerobic process and 
potentially a source of carbon in microalgae production. 
Biological wastewater treatment provides a natural means of 
degrading pollutants in wastewater using microorganisms and oxygen. 
The microorganisms break down the carbon in the organic material to 
CO
2 
and water, similar to other aerobic digestion processes. CO
2 
con -
centrations of about 0.08 to 0.23 % in the effluent from an activated 
sludge tank have been reported [78] . This minimum concentration is 
higher than that of the CO
2 
in ambient air, which provides an oppor -
tunity for use in microalgae cultivation. 
Composting of solid and semi-solid organic materials is also a CO
2 
source. The importance of CO
2 
recovery from composting crop residues 
and urban biowaste for use in controlled environment agriculture crop 
production has been reported [79] . However, the authors highlighted 
the challenges of excess CO
2 
generated in the continuous composting 
process in contrast to the diurnal dependent crop production in 
controlled environment agriculture. The storage of excess CO
2 
produced 
during the night for use when the crops require it increases the oppor -
tunity of utilisation [79] . Similarly, the CO
2 
from composting can be 
used in microalgae cultivation to replace other carbon sources. 
A feasibility study of cultivating microalgae using composting CO
2
, 
the wastewater and Compost and also CO
2 
from biogas of microalgal 
biomass anaerobic digestion has been reported [80] . While the report 
remains a feasibility study, it presented a circular economy approach in 
integrating composting and anaerobic digestion with microalgal culti -
vation. However, an experimental study integrating composting (pig

4. Microalgae cultivation parameters 
Microalgal species and physico-chemical process (biotechnological 
factors), CO
2 
concentrations, temperature, light colour and intensity, 
nutrient availability, pH, and aeration/agitation are some of the influ -
encing factors (technological and operational) in microalgal cultivation. 
The response parameters include biomass yield, chlorophyll a and b and 
carotenoids, lipid, carbohydrate and protein contents, fatty acid methyl 
esters, and microalgal concentration. Optimisation of these factors are 
necessary in achieving technological and economic efficiency of the 
systems [88] .

high and low temperatures could damage the chlorophylls of microalgal

and carotenoid content [89] . The instantaneous growth rate of Scene -

◦
C 
[90] . Similar positive temperature effects were found for biomass yield

4.2. Light 
As with carbon dioxide and other nutrients, light is a critical 
requirement for microalgae growth. Very low and high light intensities 
could be detrimental to the growth of microalgae. The different vari -
ables associated with the use of light in microalgae cultivation include 
light – dark photoperiods, frequency, light source, intensity, spectra, and 
light-exposed surface area. These parameters influence lipid, carbohy -
drate, protein, vitamin, pigment, and antioxidants contents [14] . Light 
sources include natural light, unidirectional and bidirectional lighting 
using Light-emitting diodes (LEDs) [103] . Other sources of light are 
fluorescent tubes, high intensity discharge lamps, and incandescent 
bulbs [104] . LEDs have narrow wavelength, low heat dissipation, 
compact size and flexible particularly in internal illuminated photo -
bioreactors [104,105] . 
The use of artificial light has shown to benefit microalgal produc -
tivity, especially in closed photobioreactors [103] . Light wavelength 
also plays an important role in electron excitation. Blue LED light has 40 
% more energy than red light [104] and controls key enzymes in tri -
glyceride accumulation in photosynthesis [105] . The red light emits 
twice and three times as many photos as blue and green lights,

4.4. pH 
The effect of low pH is attributed to the dissolubility of most parti -
cles, making nutrients available for use in microalgae cultivation [107] . 
An optimum pH range of 9.5 – 10.5 for Spirulina in the open pond has 
been observed [91] while 6.0 – 8.0 was recorded for Chlorella [108] . 
This is a clear indication of the variability in pH requirements by 
microalgae [109] , which will directly affect CO
2 
as an input to the 
culture medium. Extreme cases have been reported where some 
microalgae strains can grow in highly acidic conditions ( Stichococcus 
bacillaris ) and in highly alkaline conditions ( S. platensis ) [109] . Acidity 
medium due to low pH could lead to the acidification of chloroplasts and 
cytoplasmic compartments [110] . This was attributed inhibition of 
carbonic anhydrase activity due to acidity of the culture medium (BG-11 
medium) caused by higher CO
2 
concentration [47] . Other studies also 
agreed that excess CO
2 
leads to lower pH [109,110] . Inhibited carbonic 
anhydrase activity leads to reduced microalgal growth and CO
2 
fixation. 
However, low pH reduced volatilisation of ammonium nitrogen (NH
4
+
- 
N) [110] . This is particularly important as NH
4
+
-N is a nitrogen source for 
microalgae growth. A balance is needed between reducing volatilisation 
of ammonium nitrogen and the inhibition of anhydrase activity due by 
acidity. The use of alkaline digestate from anaerobic digestion with a 
high ammonium content as a nitrogen source and increased CO
2 
in the 
medium provides an opportunity for higher CO
2 
fixation. pH was 
reduced to limit NH
4
+
evaporation, when using high alkaline digestate as 
a substrate, resulting in better growth rate and dry weight [107] . At high 
concentrations, CO
2 
in water can be converted to carbonic acid, which 
reduces the culture pH. Acidic medium inhibits RuBisCO activity [14] . 
Proper CO
2 
control is required to maintain the optimum pH and at the 
same time the growth medium characteristics can provide the optimum 
initial pH, reducing the need for pH adjustment with inorganic sub -
stances and the associated costs.

To ensure CO
2 
fixation by microalgae cells, the gas delivery medium 
is critical. The CO
2 
is injected into the growth medium to provide a 
carbon source for microalgae. While the very low concentration of CO
2 
in air is a challenge, the nature of CO
2 
in the growth medium is a limiting 
factor [109] . In order to keep the microalgal culture healthy, reduce cell 
settling, expose the cells to light, enhance gas – liquid transfer, improve 
nutrient distribution, disperse produced oxygen, and avoid heat build- 
up, mixing of the microalgal culture is required [109,111] . Sparging 
serves the purpose of CO
2 
dissolution, continuous culture mixing, and O
2 
removal [109] in both open and closed microalgal systems. At an 
aeration rate of 14 Lmin
� 1

2

� 1

� 1

[112] . However, excessive sparging could lead to impaired growth and 
increased lipid synthesis [14] . Increased lipid content with reduced fatty 
acid methyl ester may occur as a response mechanism by microalgae. 
4.6. Microalgae species 
Microalgae respond differently to different process and environ -
mental conditions, including CO
2 
concentration. For example, Scene -
desmus is reported to be more tolerant of higher CO
2 
concentrations than 
Chlorella . However, 100 % CO
2

2 
[13] . Scenedesmus and Chlorella had about the same growth rate when 
the CO
2

study, a tolerance of 10 % CO
2 
for Scenedesmus obliquus in autotrophic 
mode was observed [40] . The Chlorella fusca could fix 2.6 times more 
CO
2 
from coal flue gas than Spirulina sp . [101] . On the other hand, 
Euglena gracilis growth is suitable in the CO
2 
concentration range of 5 – 
40 % and above 45 %, photosystem II activity was reported to have been 
suppressed [114] . Chlorella pyrenoidosa , Selenastrum capricornutum ,

mellococcus chodat , C. pyrenoidosa , and S. obliquus were reported to grow 
at CO
2

-1 
(75 % of wastewater and 25 % seawater) 
and 0.48 d
-1 
(25 % wastewater and 75 % seawater), respectively [115] .

5. Nutrient recovery and waste stabilisation 
Waste media can also be used to grow microalgae, providing a source 
of nutrients and a means of waste management. One of the challenges of 
large-scale production of microalgae is the high amount of nutrient 
requirement. The most important nutrients are nitrogen, phosphorus, 
and potassium, while trace elements such as cobalt, zinc, molybdenum, 
and manganese are also useful for microalgae growth. These nutrients 
must be supplied in the right quantities to ensure high productivity and 
cost efficiency. The cost of fertiliser in a raceway (10 ha) and tubular 
photobioreactor (650 m
2 
(surface area) and 30 m
3 
(volume)) for biofuel 
production using S. almeriensis was reported to be about 3 % of the total 
operating costs [116] . While the fertilizer cost is significantly low when 
compared with that of CO
2
, water, and electricity costs; to improve the 
circular economy of microalgae production combined with biochemical 
systems, organic waste from these processes will be the only source of 
nutrients in addition to the generated CO
2
. The use of synthetic media is 
a limitation for large-scale microalgae production and is also 
unsustainable.

Microalgal strains respond differently to digestate from different 
waste sources. For example, higher dry weights of Chlorella vulgaris and

6. Challenges associated with enhancing circular economy in 
biochemical systems 
6.1. High energy consumption 
Agitation, mixing, harvesting, and irradiation are operations that are 
energy-intensive [149] , depending on the scale of operation, season, and 
region of the world. These individual processes contribute to the cost of 
microalgal systems. Especially, in photobioreactors, the need to control 
the culture conditions and reduce contamination makes the system more 
expensive and energy consuming [102] . The high energy requirement is 
a challenge in improving the circular economy of microalgae cultivation 
utilising CO
2 
from biochemical systems, especially if the energy comes 
from a different source. Approximately, 1300 kWh is required per tonne 
of biomass – about half of which is used for thermal drying while the rest 
is electricity for cultivation and harvesting [103] . The high energy de -
mand can be reduced by using smarter equipment, such as efficient 
pumps and low-energy light bulbs. For example, when using bubbling 
beds, high efficiency means a high rate of CO
2 
absorption in the 
medium. 
6.2. High nutrient requirement 
Nutrients ’ limitation is challenging when they are sourced from 
outside the biochemical systems, especially from inorganic fertiliser.

The high energy requirement is 
a challenge in improving the circular economy of microalgae cultivation 
utilising CO
2 
from biochemical systems, especially if the energy comes 
from a different source. Approximately, 1300 kWh is required per tonne 
of biomass – about half of which is used for thermal drying while the rest 
is electricity for cultivation and harvesting [103] . The high energy de -
mand can be reduced by using smarter equipment, such as efficient 
pumps and low-energy light bulbs. For example, when using bubbling 
beds, high efficiency means a high rate of CO
2 
absorption in the 
medium. 
6.2. High nutrient requirement 
Nutrients ’ limitation is challenging when they are sourced from 
outside the biochemical systems, especially from inorganic fertiliser. 
The high energy requirement for the production of inorganic fertiliser 
result in more emissions [150] . The challenges include the cost of fer -
tilizer and transportation to the microalgae production site. The use of 
BG-11 medium was more expensive than kitchen waste digestate per 
kilogram biomass produced [129] . However, a higher biomass concen -
tration with BG-11 medium than with kitchen waste digestate has been 
demonstrated [129] . Potassium sulfate is used as a coagulant in the 
harvesting process [151] and is a source of concern in terms of sus -
tainability. Transportation of materials, especially nutrients, in a linear 
system is a source of emissions and resource depletion and is more sig -
nificant when the ponds/reactors are located far away from the CO
2 
source. This requires the transport of all resources, including CO
2 
and 
organic fertiliser, to the farm site. The reuse of wastewater as alternative 
nutrient sources leads to cost reduction in sourcing nutrients [152] . 
Conventional wastewater treatment incurs cost, leads to greenhouse 
gases emissions and requires high energy input [152,153] . These can be 
avoided when wastewater is used in microalgal cultivation.

6.3. Seasonal variability 
While open large-scale microalgae ponds are cost-effective, micro -
bial infestation is a source of concern [154] . The limiting factor for 
enclosed large-scale photobioreactors is the high cost of construction. In 
the temperate regions of the world, low temperatures and photoperiods 
in the winter limit microalgal production especially in outdoor systems. 
Complete reliance on indoor systems increases the overall cost of 
microalgal biomass per kilogram. Sawaengsak et al. [154] reported a 
factor of 8.0 difference in the cost of microalgae production compared to 
photobioreactors. 
6.4. Operational efficiency and scalability of the process 
Better and advanced systems are needed to improve microalgae CO
2 
fixation, photosynthetic efficiency, oxygen and excess CO
2 
removal, and 
enhanced nutrient removal efficiency. Low efficiencies can increase 
energy consumption and costs. Higher CO
2 
levels increase the acidity 
and toxicity of the culture medium. This requires a balance between CO
2 
demand and optimal pH level. In most cases, an automated system is 
used to stop CO
2 
addition when the pH reaches a critical point [109] . In 
the microalgae culture, CO
2 
is consumed during the photosynthetic 
process to produce oxygen. The O
2 
follows a two-step pathway, both in 
the microalgae culture as dissolved oxygen and in the gas phase. Dis -
solved oxygen of about 40 mgL
-1 
or 500 % oxygen concentration due to 
minimal water circulation and turbulence will inhibit photosynthesis 
and microalgal growth [13,93] and cause oxidative stress [109] . Spe -
cifically, a range of 30 – 32 mgO
2
L
-1 
dissolved oxygen has been reported 
to reduce chlorophyll fluorescence yield by 15 % [93] . The effect of 
dissolved oxygen on Arthrospira platensis has also been reported [155] . It 
is more challenging when ambient air is used as CO
2 
source, as the 
additional O
2 
from the air contributes to the dissolved oxygen content 
[18] . Therefore, a high CO
2
/O
2 
ratio of the input gas is encouraged in 
the microalgae culture. In addition, circulation of the culture medium 
and increased turbulence are effective ways to reduce dissolved oxygen 
levels and de-gas the medium. High circulation rates and turbulence are 
energy consuming and add to the operational costs, cell dry weight 
concentration and oxygen production rate. 
Efficiency, environmental benefits, and profitability depends on the 
large scale microalgal biomass production. These will require necessary 
improvements through laboratory, pilot and large-scale optimisation. 
Microalgae selection, microlagal performance under different CO
2 
concentrations and gas stream properties, temperature, medium pH, are 
studied under laboratory research while improvements in these condi -
tions are needed in pilot-scale research [156] . Competitiveness in mass 
production and optimization processes are required in large-scale

6.5. End-use requirements 
An important consideration in microalgae cultivation is the end use. 
Microalgae lipid content is optimised if the purpose of production is 
ethanol. Ethanol is an alternative biofuel to fossil fuels. Botryococcus 
braunii contains between 25 and 75 % fat and is suitable as a biofuel 
feedstock [156] . Other properties are biomass yield, CO
2 
sequestration, 
nutrient removal efficiency, and carbohydrate, protein, vitamin, 
pigment and antioxidant contents. Different cultivation practices favour 
more lipid content/yield than biomass and vice versa. Similarly, CO
2 
source may be less of a concern when producing microalgae for biofuel 
than for pharmaceutical, food and feed production. The less contami -
nated gas stream will be more suitable for food/ pharmaceutical appli -
cations. Therefore, these variations in end-use make commercial 
microalgae production a very specialised venture and in biochemical 
systems require a predefined end-use. Depending on CO
2 
source, heavy 
metals in the gas stream can damage the chloroplast of the endoplasmic 
reticulum, resulting in reduced fatty acid methyl esters [157] . Carbon 
dioxide from composting, anaerobic digestion and ethanol fermentation 
contains relatively low levels of other gaseous impurity when compared 
to flue gas from fossil fuel or biomass combustion. 
7. Future prospects 
The integration of microalgae production with biochemical systems 
offers new a business model to sequester CO
2 
and recover nutrients from 
co-products and waste. In particular, composting, anaerobic digestion, 
and ethanol fermentation processes can generate all nutrients needed for 
microalgae cultivation to the potential level of self-sufficiency. In 
anaerobic digestion system, biogas can provide energy while the CO
2 
in 
the flue gas is fixed by microalgae. Fig. 3 shows a flow chart of a model 
integrated microalgae cultivation – anaerobic digestion system. In 
composting, nutrients from the compost and leachate can support or 
meet microalgae needs. A flow chart for an anticipated integration of 
microalgae cultivation - composting system is shown in Fig. 4 . 
Similarly, CO
2 
fixation from combustion of excess ethanol for in -
ternal energy requirements in fermentation process can be imple -
mented. Fig. 5 shows a flow chart of the model integrated microalgae 
cultivation – ethanol fermentation system. The three models provide an 
opportunity for reuse of recovered water from microalgae harvesting. 
The use of microalgae for animal feed and human consumption is 
significantly different from a linear system where it is used for fuel 
production (biodiesel, bio-hydrogen or biogas). In the later, the biogenic 
CO
2 
is released directly into the atmosphere. Further research is needed 
to demonstrate these proposed systems for cost of production, and water 
and energy requirements comparisons with existing alternatives for in- 
depth understanding of the economy of scale. Additionally, more 
research is needed to reduce high energy consumption in microalgae 
harvesting, drying, oil extraction or transformation to end product. 
Techno-economic and life cycle assessment are also needed at large- 
scale to understand cost and environmental impacts relative to alter -
native technologies or products and to increase profitability. Of partic -
ular interests are optimum processes parameters to overcome limitations 
of each of the biochemical systems including gas stream purity and 
quantity and quality of the nutrient-rich liquid wastes. 
8. Conclusion 
This paper has provided information on the current status of inte -
grating microalgae cultivation with biochemical systems to enhance the 
circular economy drive. There is increasing research interest on inte -
grating microalgal cultivation with either of composting, anaerobic 
digestion or ethanol fermentation, taking into account the generated 
CO
2 
and nutrient-rich wastewater from these processes. This study 
presented an overview of carbon capture and utilisation providing a 
clear difference between microalgae carbon capture and other carbon 
capture technologies. Secondly, details of integrated microalgal culti -
vation and biochemical systems are presented. Then, operating param -
eters and nutrient recovery in microalgae cultivation are discussed. 
Finally, the challenges and future prospects of integrating microalgal 
cultivation and biochemical are presented with different models of these 
systems. 
Of particular importance in this concept is the use of nutrients 
extracted from compost as a biological alternative.

eters and nutrient recovery in microalgae cultivation are discussed. 
Finally, the challenges and future prospects of integrating microalgal 
cultivation and biochemical are presented with different models of these 
systems. 
Of particular importance in this concept is the use of nutrients 
extracted from compost as a biological alternative. Use of organic source 
of nutrient provide option for cost effective and environmental friendly 
large microalgae production. One of the challenges of CO
2 
capture is the 
removal of other gases or the recovery of CO
2 
from the target gas stream. 
While composting off-gas and biogas may require additional treatment 
before use in a microagal system, the purity of CO
2 
from ethanol 
fermentation provides unique advantage in comparison with other 
sources of carbon for microalgae cultivation. For example, high O

2

4 
separation in biogas before use in 
microalgal cultivation especially in large scale system. Some of these 
challenges can be mitigated through adjusting microalgae cultivation 
parameters, which include light, temperature, carbon dioxide, pH, and 
aeration. Efforts to mitigate climate change will be more effective with a 
circular economy. Microalgae production offers a faster path to a net- 
zero economy. For example, when used as animal feed or human food, 
it closes the loop of CO
2 
emissions while replacing other feed sources 
and their associated emissions. It is more impactful in animal production 
facilities where animal manure is available for biogas and digestate 
production, and with a high potential to integrate microalgae cultiva -
tion/biogas upgrading and composting. Additionally, microalgae are an 
alternative source of oil and could reduce ecological impact and land use 
with the associated greenhouse gases emissions in a net zero and circular 
system. To realise the benefits in climate change mitigation, more pilot 
scale projects are needed for each of these processes to demonstrate best 
practices.
